title: Vikingskipet
text:
Vikingskipet ("The Viking Ship"), officially known as Hamar Olympic Hall (), is an indoor <a href="Multi-purpose%20stadium">multi-use</a> sport and event venue in <a href="Hamar">Hamar</a>, <a href="Norway">Norway</a>. It was built as the <a href="speed%20skating%20rink">speed skating rink</a> for the <a href="1994%20Winter%20Olympics">1994 Winter Olympics</a>, and has since also hosted events and tournaments in <a href="ice%20speedway">ice speedway</a>, <a href="rallying">rally</a>, <a href="association%20football">association football</a>, <a href="bandy">bandy</a>, <a href="ice%20sledge%20speed%20racing">ice sledge speed racing</a>, <a href="flying%20disc">flying disc</a> and <a href="track%20cycling">track cycling</a>. The arena is also used for <a href="concert">concert</a>s, <a href="trade%20fair">trade fair</a> and the annual computer party <a href="The%20Gathering%20%28computer%20party%29">The Gathering</a>. It is the home arena of <a href="Hamar%20IL">Hamar IL</a> bandy team. The venue is owned by <a href="Hamar%20Municipality">Hamar Municipality</a>, and along with <a href="Hamar%20Olympic%20Amphitheatre">Hamar Olympic Amphitheatre</a> is run by the municipal Hamar Olympiske Anlegg. Vikingskipet has a capacity for 10,600 spectators during sporting events and 20,000 during concerts.
The arena was designed by <a href="Niels%20Torp">Niels Torp</a>, and <a href="Biong%20%26amp%3B%20Biong">Biong & Biong</a>, and opened on 19 December 1992. The complex cost 230 million <a href="Norwegian%20krone">Norwegian krone</a> (NOK). The localization was controversial, as it is located at <a href="%C3%85kervika">Åkervika</a>, a <a href="Ramsar%20site">Ramsar site</a>. It is Norway's national venue for speed skating and bandy, and holds annual <a href="ISU%20Speed%20Skating%20World%20Cup">ISU Speed Skating World Cup</a> races, as well as regular world championships. It has among other things hosted tournaments of the <a href="World%20Allround%20Speed%20Skating%20Championships">World Allround Speed Skating Championships</a>, <a href="European%20Speed%20Skating%20Championships">European Speed Skating Championships</a>, <a href="World%20Single%20Distance%20Championships">World Single Distance Championships</a>, <a href="World%20Sprint%20Speed%20Skating%20Championships">World Sprint Speed Skating Championships</a>, <a href="UCI%20Track%20Cycling%20World%20Championships">UCI Track Cycling World Championships</a>, <a href="Speedway%20Grand%20Prix">Speedway Grand Prix</a> and <a href="World%20Rally%20Championship">World Rally Championship</a>.
Construction.
During the process of the <a href="Lillehammer%20bid%20for%20the%201992%20Winter%20Olympics">Lillehammer bid for the 1992 Winter Olympics</a>, the <a href="International%20Olympic%20Committee">International Olympic Committee</a> had not specified that it was necessary with an indoor speed skating rink. <a href="Calgary">Calgary</a> had used the indoor <a href="Olympic%20Oval">Olympic Oval</a> during the <a href="1988%20Winter%20Olympics">1988 Winter Olympics</a>, but <a href="Albertville">Albertville</a>, who were awarded the <a href="1992%20Winter%20Olympics">1992 Winter Olympics</a>, had opted for the outdoor <a href="L%27anneau%20de%20vitesse">L'anneau de vitesse</a>. In its bid, the speed skating events were planned held at <a href="Stampesletta">Stampesletta</a>, an outdoor track and field stadium in Lillehammer. Only after Lillehammer had been awarded the 1994 Winter Olympics was it decided that an indoor venue would have to be built for the games.
Hamar had previously been a venue for international speed skating events at <a href="Hamar%20stadion">Hamar stadion</a>. The town was therefore selected to host the two skating venues. In December 1989, it was decided that the new venue would be built at Åkervika, a Ramsar site outside downtown Hamar. A compromise was reached whereby the stadium was moved from its original location, two birdwatching towers were built, and a lumber yard was moved. <a href="Nature%20and%20Youth">Nature and Youth</a> remained opposed to the plans, stating the location "has destroyed part of one of the world's most important bird reserves".
The construction was passed by the <a href="Parliament%20of%20Norway">Parliament of Norway</a> in April 1990. Architects were Niels Torp, and Biong and Biong. Ole K. Karlsen was selected to build the building, in competition with eleven other contractors. The ventilation contract worth NOK 18 million had originally been awarded to Hagen & Haugan on 29 May 1991. Two days later, the <a href="Lillehammer%20Olympic%20Organizing%20Committee">Lillehammer Olympic Organizing Committee</a> signed a sponsorship agreement with Norsk Viftefabrikk and <a href="Elektrisk%20Bureau">Elektrisk Bureau</a>, both part of <a href="Asea%20Brown%20Boveri">Asea Brown Boveri</a>, which demanded discounts in their sponsorship payments for not receiving the contract. In September 1992, Investa, which owned Ole K. Karlsen, filed for bankruptcy, causing delays in construction. When it opened, Vikingskipet was the largest indoor sports venue in the world, and has twice the spectator capacity of the Olympic Oval. The ice rink was first tested on 15 December 1992, and officially opened on 19 December.
The construction of the venue cost NOK 230 million, which was almost entirely financed through state grants. Hamar Municipality contributed by building a co-located fire station for NOK 21 million. Local businesses also contributed with NOK 8 million. <a href="Moelven%20Industrier">Moelven Industrier</a> and <a href="Fireguard%20%28company%29">Fireguard</a> both contributed in exchange for being able to use the venues for marketing large wooden structures. To finance the operating deficit after the Olympics, Hamar Municipality received a capital grant of NOK 30 million, with the interest going to pay for running Vikingskipet and Hamar Olympic Amphitheatre. Operating costs were estimated at NOK 7 million per year; the venue will receive income of NOK 1 million from larger events, NOK 1 million will come from free work from the fire department, and NOK 1 million from advertisements. Similar to Hamar Olympic Amphitheatre, the venue has two official names, Hamar Olympic Hall and Vikingskipet. The former cannot be used commercially by non-Olympic events, such as in merchandise.
Facilities.
The venue has a floor area of and a volume of . The hall has a spectator capacity of 10,600 people, of which 2,000 can be seated. During the Olympics, this included 250 VIP seats, 250 press seats and 100 commentator seats. Access to the inner ring can be provided via an underpass. Lighting is provided at 1,400 <a href="lux">lux</a>, while the venue has a ventilation system capable of both heating and cooling, as well as de-moisturizing, and both re-use and circulation of air. The refrigeration unit uses an <a href="ammonia">ammonia</a> and <a href="saline%20water">saline</a> solution, which is transported in pipes within the concrete, which allows for an ice temperature of between −5.5 and −6.5 degrees Celsius (22 and 20 °F). The heat from the refrigerating unit can be reused.
The rink itself is long, with a turning radius of . Within the speed skating rink lies a bandy field. The venue was designed to also allow for association football, cycling, <a href="track%20and%20field">track and field</a>, <a href="curling">curling</a>, <a href="motorsports">motorsports</a> and <a href="cross-country%20skiing%20%28sport%29">cross-country skiing</a>. The inside of the track can also be used for association football, with pitch dimensions up to . It can also function as an indoor <a href="driving%20range">driving range</a> for <a href="golf">golf</a>. The name derives from the roof looking like the <a href="keel">keel</a> of a <a href="Viking%20ship">Viking ship</a>. The building is visible from the <a href="European%20route%20E6">E6</a> motorway and the <a href="Dovre%20Line">Dovre Line</a> passing through Hamar, and was planned to be Hamar's main <a href="landmark">landmark</a>.
Transport.
During the Olympics, transport was in part provided by <a href="Vikingskipet%20Station">Vikingskipet Station</a> on the <a href="R%C3%B8ros%20Line">Røros Line</a>, which passes right next to the venue. The station is a <a href="cul-de-sac">cul-de-sac</a> station which is <a href="railway%20electrification%20system">electrified</a> and allowed trains during the Olympics and the Track Cycling World Championships to reach the venue within a short walk from the train. The station was officially opened on 16 August 1993. The station has not been used since the Olympics. In 2006, the <a href="Norwegian%20National%20Rail%20Administration">Norwegian National Rail Administration</a> proposed re-opening the station in conjunction with larger events.
Events.
Prior to the Olympic Games, the venue hosted three <a href="world%20championship">world championship</a>s in 1993. In February, it hosted all but two preliminary matches of the <a href="1993%20Bandy%20World%20Championship">1993 Bandy World Championship</a>. To make the games more attractive, preliminary round matches were reduced from 90 to 60 minutes. The final was spectated by 5,338 people. For four months, the venue was equipped with a <a href="velodrome">velodrome</a>, which allowed the venue to host the <a href="1993%20UCI%20Track%20Cycling%20World%20Championships">1993 UCI Track Cycling World Championships</a>. The velodrome cost NOK 95 million less than building a permanent velodrome in <a href="Oslo">Oslo</a>, which would be hosting the <a href="1993%20UCI%20Road%20World%20Championships">1993 UCI Road World Championships</a>. The <a href="Norwegian%20Cycling%20Federation">Norwegian Cycling Federation</a> had originally bid for the championships to get a permanent velodrome built at <a href="Hasle%2C%20Oslo">Hasle</a> in Oslo, but declined the offer and instead chose the temporary concept. Because the velodrome only has a circumference of , the venue's spectator capacity was reduced to 3,000 people.
Hamar was the center for skating sports during the 1994 Winter Olympics. The other venue in town was Hamar Olympic Amphitheatre, which featured the <a href="Short%20track%20speed%20skating%20at%20the%201994%20Winter%20Olympics">short track speed skating</a> and <a href="Figure%20skating%20at%20the%201994%20Winter%20Olympics">figure skating</a> events. Vikingskipet held ten <a href="speed%20skating%20at%20the%201994%20Winter%20Olympics">speed skating</a> events, five for men and five for women. Norway's <a href="Johann%20Olav%20Koss">Johann Olav Koss</a> took three golds, in the <a href="Speed%20skating%20at%20the%201994%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%201500%20metres">men's 1,500 meters</a>, <a href="Speed%20skating%20at%20the%201994%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%205000%20metres">5000 meters</a> and <a href="Speed%20skating%20at%20the%201994%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%2010000%20metres">10000 meters</a>. In the latter two, he finished ahead of fellow countryman <a href="Kjell%20Storelid">Kjell Storelid</a>. The <a href="Speed%20skating%20at%20the%201994%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%20500%20metres">men's 500 meters</a> was won by Russia's <a href="Aleksandr%20Golubev%20%28speed%20skater%29">Aleksandr Golubev</a> ahead of fellow countryman <a href="Sergey%20Klevchenya">Sergey Klevchenya</a>, while the <a href="Speed%20skating%20at%20the%201994%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Men%27s%201000%20metres">men's 1000 meters</a> was won by American <a href="Dan%20Jansen">Dan Jansen</a>. Koss and Jansen won their olympic golds setting new world record time on their distances. For women, American <a href="Bonnie%20Blair">Bonnie Blair</a> defended her two 1992 golds in <a href="Speed%20skating%20at%20the%201994%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%20500%20metres">500 meters</a> and <a href="Speed%20skating%20at%20the%201994%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%201000%20metres">1000 meters</a>. Austria's <a href="Emese%20Hunyady">Emese Hunyady</a> won the <a href="Speed%20skating%20at%20the%201994%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%201500%20metres">1500 meters</a> ahead of Russia's <a href="Svetlana%20Bazhanova">Svetlana Bazhanova</a> and Germany's <a href="Gunda%20Niemann">Gunda Niemann</a>. However, Bazhanova took gold ahead of Nemeth-Hunyady on the <a href="Speed%20skating%20at%20the%201994%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%203000%20metres">3000 meters</a>, with Germany's <a href="Claudia%20Pechstein">Claudia Pechstein</a> in third. Pechstein would go on to win the <a href="Speed%20skating%20at%20the%201994%20Winter%20Olympics%20%E2%80%93%20Women%27s%205000%20metres">5000 meters</a> ahead of Niemann.
Vikingskipet was proposed to also host <a href="curling%20at%20the%20Winter%20Olympics">curling</a>, should it be included in the Olympic program. It had been a <a href="demonstration%20sport">demonstration sport</a> in <a href="curling%20at%20the%201988%20Winter%20Olympics">1988</a> and <a href="curling%20at%20the%201992%20Winter%20Olympics">1992</a> Olympics, but was eventually discarded from the Lillehammer program. The event would have used the same production equipment as for speed skating, and would have consisted of a four-team tournament for both men and women, and would have been held during the Games' two last days. Vikingskipet was the venue for <a href="Ice%20sledge%20speed%20racing%20at%20the%201994%20Winter%20Paralympics">ice sledge speed skating</a> during the 1994 Winter Paralympics. Eight events were held, four for women and four for men. The event had 22 participants from 7 nations competing for 24 medals, resulting in 23 of 24 medals being awarded to Norwegian athletes. <a href="Atle%20Haglund">Atle Haglund</a> set two world records.
The venue is the national stadium for speed skating in Norway. It hosts annual <a href="ISU%20Speed%20Skating%20World%20Cup">ISU Speed Skating World Cup</a>, and has in addition hosted many European and world championships. This includes the <a href="World%20Allround%20Speed%20Skating%20Championships">World Allround Speed Skating Championships</a> in <a href="1993%20World%20Allround%20Speed%20Skating%20Championships%20for%20Men">1993 (for men)</a>, <a href="1999%20World%20Allround%20Speed%20Skating%20Championships">1999</a>, <a href="2004%20World%20Allround%20Speed%20Skating%20Championships">2004</a>, <a href="2009%20World%20Allround%20Speed%20Skating%20Championships">2009</a>, <a href="2013%20World%20Allround%20Speed%20Skating%20Championships">2013</a> and <a href="2017%20World%20Allround%20Speed%20Skating%20Championships">2017</a> tournaments. The <a href="World%20Sprint%20Speed%20Skating%20Championships">World Sprint Speed Skating Championships</a> has been held in <a href="1997%20World%20Sprint%20Speed%20Skating%20Championships">1997</a>, <a href="2002%20World%20Sprint%20Speed%20Skating%20Championships">2002</a> and <a href="2007%20World%20Sprint%20Speed%20Skating%20Championships">2007</a>, while the <a href="World%20Single%20Distance%20Championships">World Single Distance Championships</a> was held in <a href="1996%20World%20Single%20Distance%20Championships">1996</a>. The <a href="European%20Speed%20Skating%20Championships">European Speed Skating Championships</a> has been held four times, in <a href="1994%20European%20Speed%20Skating%20Championships">1994</a>, <a href="2000%20European%20Speed%20Skating%20Championships">2000</a>, <a href="2006%20European%20Speed%20Skating%20Championships">2006</a>, <a href="2010%20European%20Speed%20Skating%20Championships">2010</a> and <a href="2014%20European%20Speed%20Skating%20Championships">2014</a>.
Since 1996, Vikingskipet has hosted <a href="The%20Gathering%20%28computer%20party%29">The Gathering</a>, a <a href="computer%20party">computer party</a> which is held every Easter. Concerts held at Vikingskipet include <a href="Andrea%20Bocelli">Andrea Bocelli</a> (2005), <a href="Beyonc%C3%A9">Beyoncé</a> (2007), <a href="Cliff%20Richard">Cliff Richard</a> (2007), and <a href="Stevie%20Wonder">Stevie Wonder</a> (2008).
The <a href="Norway%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Norway women's national football team</a> played <a href="Sweden%20women%27s%20national%20football%20team">Sweden</a> on 21 January 1996, winning 4–0. Vikingskipet hosted a round of the <a href="Speedway%20Grand%20Prix">Speedway Grand Prix</a> in <a href="2002%20Speedway%20Grand%20Prix">2002</a>, <a href="2003%20Speedway%20Grand%20Prix">2003</a> and <a href="2004%20Speedway%20Grand%20Prix">2004</a>. It was also the service depot and race headquarters for <a href="Rally%20Norway">Rally Norway</a>, which was arranged in 2006, <a href="2007%20Rally%20Norway">2007</a> and <a href="2009%20Rally%20Norway">2009</a>. The latter two were part of the <a href="World%20Rally%20Championship">World Rally Championship</a>.
In March 2011, the <a href="Norwegian%20Skating%20Association">Norwegian Skating Association</a> announced that they indented that the Norwegian World Cup events would be moved to <a href="S%C3%B8rmarka%20Arena">Sørmarka Arena</a> in <a href="Stavanger">Stavanger</a>, due to low attendance at Vikingskipet. Vikingskipet has been selected to host the <a href="2013%20World%20Allround%20Speed%20Skating%20Championships">2013 World Allround Speed Skating Championships</a>. Lillehammer is scheduled to host the <a href="2016%20Winter%20Youth%20Olympics">2016 Winter Youth Olympics</a>, with Vikingskipet to host long track speed skating events.
Rink records.
Vikingskipet is one of few indoor speed skating venues in the world, which has allowed for many world records. The following is a list of the rink records, including the distance, gender, the record time, the athlete who set the record, the country they represent, and the date the record was set.
World records.
Vikingskipet has been the venues for <a href="world%20record">world record</a>s in speed skating, track cycling, ice sledge speed racing and frisbee. The following is a list of world records set in Vikingskipet, including the sport, event, gender, time or distance, the athlete, their country and the date the record was set. During the 1994 Winter Olympics, four of the five distances for men's speed skating received new world records.
